abstract.p: Ronald Radosh letter responds to Victor Navasky Oct 21 Op-Ed article; holds that thousands of pages of documentation have become available on assistance given to Soviet espionage by American Communist Party

block.p: In his Oct. 21 Op-Ed article, Victor Navasky attacks a ''new cadre of cold war historians,'' and I am obviously among his targets. This cadre, he says, ''seems intent on seizing fragments from cold war archives, ambiguous intercepts from cables between Moscow and its American-based agents and other ephemera to prove that the American Communist Party was indeed at the center of a nest of spies.''

In his Oct. 21 Op-Ed article, Victor Navasky attacks a ''new cadre of cold war historians,'' and I am obviously among his targets. This cadre, he says, ''seems intent on seizing fragments from cold war archives, ambiguous intercepts from cables between Moscow and its American-based agents and other ephemera to prove that the American Communist Party was indeed at the center of a nest of spies.''

Mr. Navasky says that all of the above ''is still in dispute.'' He is wrong. Thousands of pages of documentation have become available on the assistance given to Soviet espionage by the American Communist Party and hundreds of individuals, as well as the tens of millions of dollars sent as secret subsidies to the American Communists by Moscow. That is why many revisionist historians now accept the truth.
